message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest that he may have acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. Among the options, IgA mesangial deposition is the most commonly associated finding with this type of glomerulonephritis. Splitting of the glomerular basement membrane is seen in membranous nephropathy. Crescents of fibrin and plasma proteins are seen in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. Granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 complement are seen in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest glomerulonephritis, and the most likely type is IgA mesangial deposition. Option A describes Alport syndrome, Option B describes rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, and Option D describes membranous nephropathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of sore throat and pink urine with dysmorphic RBCs suggest glomerulonephritis, and the presence of IgA suggests IgA nephropathy. Splitting of the glomerular basement membrane is seen in Alport syndrome, which usually presents with hematuria and hearing loss. Crescentic glomerulonephritis shows fibrocellular crescents and fibrinoid necrosis. Granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 are seen in membranous nephropathy and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest glomerular injury, and the presence of dysmorphic RBCs and RBC casts suggest glomerular hematuria. IgA mesangial deposition is a common finding in IgA nephropathy, which can present with recurrent episodes of gross or microscopic hematuria associated with upper respiratory tract infections. Splitting of the glomerular basement membrane and crescents of fibrin and plasma proteins are more commonly seen in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. Granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 complement are seen in membranous nephropathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest a possible glomerular disease, with IgA mesangial deposition being the most likely finding in this particular case. The other options are associated with other types of glomerular diseases.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and test results suggest glomerulonephritis, which is commonly associated with a history of streptococcal infections. Among the options, IgA mesangial deposition is most commonly associated with glomerulonephritis. Splitting of the glomerular basement membrane is seen in membranous nephropathy, crescents of fibrin and plasma proteins are seen in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, and granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 complement are seen in immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest glomerulonephritis, specifically IgA nephropathy. This is characterized by mesangial deposition of IgA. The other options are associated with other types of glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, laboratory findings, and history of previous similar episodes suggest the most likely diagnosis is IgA nephropathy, which is characterized by IgA mesangial deposition. Splitting of the glomerular basement membrane is seen in Alport syndrome, while crescents of fibrin and plasma proteins are seen in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. Granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 complement are seen in membranous nephropathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest glomerulonephritis and the laboratory studies also confirm hematuria and proteinuria. Among the options, IgA mesangial deposition is most likely associated with post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, which can occur after a strep throat infection. Splitting of the glomerular basement membrane is seen in membranous nephropathy, which is less likely in this case as there are no antibodies against phospholipase A2 receptor. Crescents of fibrin and plasma proteins are seen in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. Granular deposits of IgG, IgM and C3 complement are seen in immune complex glomerulonephritis like lupus nephritis or membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest IgA nephropathy, which is characterized by mesangial deposition of IgA. Splitting of the glomerular basement membrane is seen in membranous nephropathy, crescents of fibrin and plasma proteins are seen in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, and granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 complement are seen in immune complex glomerulonephritis.
